A few years back I made this baby: http://www.amateurengineer.com/?p=400. While it was nice to wokl with it was very unflexible so I decided to dismantle the old parts and remakre its elements as stackable modules. So here you go.
To see if you like I recomed printing a base_bottom with a length of 1 and one base_top.stl - its a prepared top to hold 10 banana-sockets for interconnect stuff.
If you have any idaeas for new modules pls comment!
Modules
Arduino:
Parts needed
  • 2 distance bolts
  • 4 fitting screws
  • Arduino
    Use: Just to have a fixed Arduino
    DUAL_DVM
  • 2 of those cheap, chinese made mini DVMs (ebay, 3€ a piece)
  • 4 2mm screws to fit to bottom
  • 6 pegnails to fit to cables
  • some length of shrinkwrap
    Use:Have two simple DVMs at hand
    CCCP_AVM
  • 1 beautiful CCCP Analog Voltmeter
  • 2 banana sockets
  • some wire
    Use: Thought more of as an example on how to do it since this VMs are made of unobtainium :(
    HD44780
  • 1 HD44780 display which measures 36 by 80 mm
  • 4 distance bolts
  • 8 fitting screws
    Use: often used standard Display

I used 4 Breadboards stuck together in the middle with 28 "fields" around them. ,My total dimensions are: 450x300 mm. I sinply used a base unitx4 to make drillsholes from the under side and little screws to fix the bottoms.

description.text: vnbvnbvnbvn

First off, I did not create this. It was designed by the Fleming Bros and released in Alibre format. I have only imported their file into Pro/Engineer and converted it to stl. I believe this is a more common format and will facilitate people being able to print or cnc it easier. For those that aren't aware, the Isaac Mendel is designed to be easily manufactured on either a 3D printer or a CNC Mill. It uses fewer parts than a traditional Mendel. However, with the release of the new Prusa Mendel it is no longer the easiest to print. Still it is a great design and hopefully these files will serve you well. I have recieved permission to publish these files from the original authors and am releasing them under the GPLv3 as was the original design. If you have a printer and print this out please post some pics as mine is not finished yet.
Thanks and happy printing. Update: Added a zip file with all the parts for easier downloading. Update 2: It has come to my attention that many of these files are dimensioned incorrectly. I'll be updating this as soon as I can correct the issue but for now be sure to double check the scaling on anything you try to print.

description.text: See it in action http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jcyL4Q-zxrg You need 4 8mm ball bearings (or similar, maybe even marbles) to use these. This is a 3 part vibration isolator. It consists of a top ball isolator. It allows the machine to move in all directions reducing the lateral movement transfered to the table. It needs a 8mm ball bearing. The bottom part is a spring that reduces any other vibrations that get past the ball isolator. It also has holders for a coil spring to take some of the weight of a heavier machine. I have also noticed since using these my registration has been better as the whole machine moves rather than the frame flexing. It is also much quiter then before. It may look a bit unstable but I have been unable to topple mine yet, even giving the machine a hard shove.

The smaller part of the ball isolator sits on top of the spring (a bit of glue is helpful here). Then the ball bearing, then the other part of the ball isolator. The machine then sits in the dips. Again a bit of glue helps here.

comments.text:
Did you have too many strings inside? I notice the model's shell is just irregular enough to cause infill (and retractions) at points all around the inside. The settings jipvanleeuwenstein used was 0.4mm shell, and I bet 0% infill, since the walls are close to 0.8mm
Just looking the the layers view in CURA I can see that 10% infill caused a lot of retractions when printing the inner circles. And 0.4mm shell and 0% infill looks way better (retraction wise). At a layer height or 0.2mm look at layer 8 especially to see the difference.
comments.author: pureluck

comments.text: Thanks, I'm testing your suggestion.  I "disassembled" the first attempt.  There were a few strings, but not enough that it should stop it from working.  I saw, 2 or 3 spread around.  May have been one or two more lost in the dismantle.  I scaled it down 50% so  that may invalidate the test, but only so much time before I need to get to work....   OK, I stopped the print half way through.  Scaling it down 50% made the walls too thin.  I'll try it again tonight at full size, and let you know how it goes.
comments.author: peetersm

comments.text: I added a photo to the "Made One" section.  I printed again at 100% scale with .2mm layer height, and shell thickness of .4, retraction enabled. Bottom/Top thickness of .4. print speed 70%  and flow 100%.  Looked great but leaked air.  So I gave it a quick cover with some silicon caulking.  Now it is a fully operational whistle.   I'll keep trying to get the settings right on this one, maybe disabling retraction, or slicing with another app.   I will need to make a dozen of each type before christmas.  I have friends with 3 children who are the right age that will need to get a few each.  Thank you for putting this up.  It's an interesting challenge to print.

comments.text:
Ciao, ma come funziona?
Ultimamente il filo mi si attorciglia spesso!
comments.author: terrornoize

comments.text:
lo metti appeso alla bobina alla spira che sta per essere usata dalla stampante, appendi un piccolo peso ai due anelli che stanno sotto per permettergli di stare orientato nel modo corretto.
Lo scopo è duplice, con il peso tiene in tensione sempre la bobina così facendo eviti che le spiri si spostino e si sovrappongano, allo stesso tempo dovrebbe (dipende dalla tensione) far scivolare l'eventuale spira che blocca quella di alimentazione con l'invito a curva dolce.
Si premette che la bobina non dovrebbe essere completamente libera di girare ma un minimo di attrito lo dovrebbe fare per mantenere meglio la tensione.
comments.author: terrornoize

author: carlomacchiavello

description.text: There didn't seem to be any CAD files for Cherry ML Keycaps so I quickly made one based on the specsheet found here: http://eicom.ru/pdf/datasheet/cherry_pdfs/keymodule/key All the major dimensions are accurate, and the rest I based off my own measurement with callipers. Fit is a little tight but it works! :)

• The pins on the bottom are really delicate so make sure you print the keycap on its side so that the 'grain' runs vertically. That should make the pins less likely to snap. I haven't had the pins snapped with this method, even with moderate pulling on the key. Printing sideways also produces a better contour.
  • I printed at a slow feed rate (20mm/s) at 0.05mm layer height. A single print took about 80mins I think.
  • You should test your keycap on a key that you are willing to lose. In the off chance that the pins snap off, its is relatively difficult to take them out. Be prepared to dig them out with a scalpel.
You want virgins? We got virgins!
Gonna need lots of support to print this.

sealing rims.
.
It's actually a little over 4" long, but will fit on a 100x100 print bed if
you rotate the z axis 23 degrees and the re-center the part; although
you either need to skip the skirt, or bring it in very close to the print
(around 0.5mm does work on a 100x100 print bed).
.
I printed in PLA with .2mm layers and 25% infill, no support.
Note that you'll need a well calibrated machine to get the hinge
to print so that it separates and swivels correctly.
.
Once complete, gently bend the parts back and forth holding it
near the center hinge. You'll feel it click loose and then should
swivel freely.

description.text:
Electrostatic generator - single disc version
Simplified ES generator with added capacitors and flash
light (measured breakdown ~ 6.5 kV). Common 9V battery to power motor and turn the disc. The disc can also be turned by hand and the charge builds up very quickly. Video: http://youtu.be/yXYd1l08RsY The video was done a second time because in the first try there
was to much background light for the camera to capture the sparks. It's better now but still missing a lot - listen to the sound. Designed and built within two days (weekend) and to be seen
as a draft version, this little machine produces a lot of current @ high voltage - always be careful! More info will follow... Additional Information - first part:
The blue wires are contacting the disc. Either thin lize wire or carbon fibre (better), the green wires end in close proximity to the disc and do not touch. Connection:
blue/top/left - connected to aluminium plate directly behind
blue/bottom/left - connects to blue/top/right
blue/bottom/right - connected to aluminium plate directly behind
green wires are output - connected with capacitor legs, parallel is the flash light or spark gap (discharges bad for your ears) backside plate added What learned - slower is better. Hyperspeed as shown in the video is nonsense. A lot of loses through fine blue mesh all over the segments (seen in the dark). Next machine might be smaller - or not depends if this discharges can be reduced somehow.

description.text: een jat

This is a pair of mirror-image rattleback models derived from jasay's original thing. When the "cw" model is spun clockwise it will reverse direction to spin counterclockwise. When the "ccw" model is spun counterclockwise it will reverse direction to spin clockwise. Demo video at http://mysd300.blogspot.com/2010/12/rattleback-twins.html

These models differ from jasay's mesh in the following ways:

  • The Z-axis height has been scaled down by 45%. (jasay has posted a comparable model)

  • The base of the model has been aligned to Z=0 for the convenience of skeinforge users.

  • The flat side faces down so Makerbot users won't need to reorient the model or use a raft.
    • (But if your build process and software can do it, I recommend building the part sideways because it'll produce smoother contours. That's how I built the rattlebacks in the video.)

Lasercut Waffle Structure Laptop Stand. Easy to use press-fit connections. Feel free to use it as you wish! It works great! I made it for my wife, whose laptop overheats whenever using photoshop or rendering an image. The design is based on being as open as possible to allow air to freely pass through on all sides and optimally cool down the device. Test it out for your self if you have access to a laser or cnc router. More variants can be found at http://www.lasercuttinglab.com

Download the .dxf file and open it up, the dxf is the only file you need if you are using 3/16" (or 4.76mm) plywood, I added the original model and a .stl as well for anyone who may want to slice it up differently (for example with 123D make which has great features) or for anyone who may want to add parts to the design or simply use it as a reference for your own design.
Note: you can slice up the segments of the design very easily, just download '23D Make' for free and import the .stl file into it. Within minutes you will have a custom sliced file ready to cut!
I used 3/16" (or 4.76mm) plywood to make my stand, if using a different size plywood make sure to rescale the interlocking slots.Again this can be done in a number of different software programs, such as the one mentioned above. I recommend using 3/16" as its cheap and thin enough for most laser cutters to easily cut. If anyone else has a good effects using a different material please let me know.
If you do not have access to a laser cutter, Laser Cutting Lab, LLC will be offering this as a complete kit for a low price. See http://www.lasercuttinglab.com for more details.
Any questions? Feel free to ask or visit us at http://www.lasercuttinglab.com.
I hope you will enjoy it!

description.text: elica

Faisant pas mal de sortie en vélo. J'en ai eu marre de devoir sortir mon téléphone pour mon suivie km, mes calorie, mon dénivelé, ect.
De plus la plupart des boitier qui existe sont fait pour le téléphone mais pas le téléphone + la protection de tout les jours.
J'ai donc créer ce support pour mon vélo, permettant d'avoir toujours le téléphone sous les yeux et sans le retirer de sa protection.
Pour le plexiglas, il faut aller au rayon tableau d'un magasin de bricolage et cela coute 2€ à couper au cutter.
J'espère que cela pourra vous aider.
Je laisse les sources si vous voulez vous en inspirer.
Faite un make si vous l'utiliser.

Making quite a ride. I got tired of having to pull out my phone to my km followed my calorie, my altitude, etc.
Also most of existing housing are made ​​to the phone but not the phone + protection every day.
So I create this support for my bike, which always have the phone in front of me and without removing it from its protection.
For Plexiglas, go to the radius picture of a DIY store and it costs € 2 cut with a knife.
I hope this can help you.
I let the sources if you want to get inspired.
Made if you make

This is a recreation of the Varvakeion Athena displayed at the National Archaeological Museum in Athens, Greece. I used a very small copy of the Athena to photograph with my Nikon D200.
If you'd like to know more about the Athena Parthenos, please follow this link: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athena_Parthenos
For the particular ancient copy of the Athena Parthenos I used to model: http://nam.culture.gr/portal/page/portal/deam/virtual_exhibitions/EAMS/EAMG129
I shot almost 200 photos then used Agisoft Photoscan to recreate the statuette.
I'm not very good at recreating small items (yet) but I thought this rough Athena was good enough to share. If anyone wants to use it or clean it up and improve on it, be my guest. There are some incredible and talented people out there.
I'm still learning how to use the many different tools in software like Photoscan, Meshmixer & Meshlab and rather than massacre the rougher models like this one, I figured I'd let someone else take it and improve on it.

Replica of a IMI Israeli Desert Eagle .50AE pistol.
Based on model created by drarhiii. Broken up to be printed on smaller printer. I changed the trigger and made spaces for allthread and nuts for a more robust design to be stronger when I use it at conventions as part of my cosplay costume.

Print the 5 individual pieces.
You will need :-
5 x 6mm hex nuts
1 x 6mm Dome nut/Acorn nut
2 lengths of allthread 6mm x 165mm
1 length of allthread 6mm x 170mm Line up the three slide pieces, slide the longer piece of allthread through the lower channel, fixing a hex nut on the internal end and using the dome nut or acorn nut on the front end.
Once this top part is secure, the remaining trigger and grip pieces can be assembled using the remaining allthread lengths and hex nuts.
The cavities for the nuts can be filled using hot glue.
The allthread can hold the pieces together securely, but I'm planning on using this as part of my cosplay costume at a convention so I wanted to make it as solid as possible.
I printed this using ABS filament so I welded/glued the pieces together using acetone before using the allthread to hold everything together. There are a number of products you can use if you print using PLA.

description.text: Here is my fan duct for version 5 of the E3D hotend.

To assemble this press the hotend firmly into the extruder. The heater block should be oriented with the heater cartridge facing away from the 40 mm duct. This is not the orientation depicted in the E3D assembly guide but it positions the heater cartridge away from the 40 mm duct and minimizes warping. You will need an 15mm M3 bolt attach the duct to the extruder.
I printed this using a 0.4 mm nozzle, infill 40%, layer 0,2mm, from ABS and PLA.

Sometimes persuading a new roll of filament to go through an extruder can be a bit of a pain. Here is how to quickly straighten and feed it.

Wave a lighter flame under the filament for a few seconds about 20mm from the end. Stretch the filament a bit while it is warm as shown - do not snap it as the end will then curl. Allow to cool, blow, or use burnt finger as heatsink.
Trim end to a stout point. This will now easily feed through most extruder mechanisms.
Vik :v)

description.text: MALE HALF OF PROPOSED DESIGN FOR NEW IRON JUG
A simplified nurby seagull. A test to see how much detail was preserved at half table size.

This is item 8 for me. It was mainly a test of how much resolution and the effect of large area raft and external support on a model with delicate features. Tested how strong the adhesion of the raft to the table would be. Very good and very tough to get off. Learning to not try to tear off raft and/or supports, just get little edges loose at a time. So this is a work in progress. Didn't sand or try to finish end product. Looking at the photo, the straightness of the beak is a little bit left of the support. Models like this probably turn out with much better resolution by splitting them in half. Super glue works fantastic on ABS and PLA.

This is a dynamic prosthesis that replaces the middle and distal phalange. This prosthesis uses living hinges and complex geometry to produce a single piece prosthetic that can be printed in one print. this model is best made with Nylon most other materials will not work. The model needs a bit of cleanup, and the print out will require some support clean up.
this was printed in nylon 618, it requires support. it will also require sizing for a proper fit. Two cuts need to be made to remove extra support material between the "phalanges".

description.text:
Fan duct for the Printrbot Simple 1405 edition. This replaces the two wooden fan mount tabs and provides much better air flow than the printable fan shroud uploaded by Printrbot. This part also provides stabilization for the extruder motor and adds some stiffness to the front of the Y axis assembly. The design accepts the original mounting screws and provides two additional holes for 10mm long lower fan mount screws, but they are not really necessary. V0.4 Updated with slot for zip-tie cable hold.
-Complete! V0.5 with better air flow
New design makes printing much easier! I've increased the airflow about 30% and I no longer have blow-back from the fan(stock printerbot fan). This new update has a flat bottom to print right side up on the build platform. I used Slic3r with a .32 layer height and small supports under the right side overhang and the inner mouth of the duct outlet.
See pics for comparison to the old design. I printed the new model in about 2 hours, but using a layer height of .2 - .3 and going a little slower should result in better layer adhesion. I have not had issues with warping from the heat off the hotend or extruder motor but I used 3 bottom layers, 4 top layers, 3 perimeters and 10% infill with my print just to be safe.
If you have any sugestions please let me know and I will try to incorporate them. Thanks for the good feedback so far!

Pikachu after a fall

This model is designed for up to FOUR different colors and should not require support.
For multi-color: Use all four of the PikaSplat stls with color names or for just dual printing use the PikaSplat-Dual.thing
For single-color: Use PikaSplat-Single.stl
PikaSplat.x3g is the file I used to print the version shown. It is set up to retract filament and the left extruder is at 210 and right at 200? C while extruding at 40mm/s & traveling at 70mm/s. Right will print out the main body (generally Yellow) and Left will print out the other parts.
PikaSplat.3dm is the Rhino file used to cut up Pikachu into five different files.

remixed_from.author: clough42
remixed_from.title: MakerFarm Prusa i3v Improved End Stop Switch Brackets

title: MakerFarm 8" i3v Y Motor Fan Mount

description.text: Note: This was made on/for the 8 inch Makerfarm i3v printer. It may not work or fit the larger versions. A mount to attach a 40mm fan to the v-slot in front of the Y-motor. Remixed from clough42's excellent endstop switch mounts, the Z switch mount in particular (I was unable to remove the switch holes, openScad didn't like my plug). 11-26-14 Update: Desiring to have the fan and Y endstop switch mounted on the same piece, I redesigned the mount from the ground up. No more stealing clough42's work. :) It's not as pretty, but it works. 11-27-14 Update: Ok, I made it a little more pretty. :)

To install, just remove the M5 bolt at the front of the printer holding the RAMPS-side Y v-slot extrusion, pull the extrusion up far enough to slip a t-nut into the slot, put the extrusion back, and replace the bolt.   
You may need to remove your Y endstop and slide its t-nut back for the fan mount, and reattach the Y endstop on the nut you just slid into the extrusion.  
New version lets you mount the Y endstop switch to the fan mount with two 10mm M3 bolts. No nuts required, the bolts thread into the mount itself.

title: Fixes for Ferguson's Mechanical Paradox Replica Thingiverse #93418

description.text:
The attached files are replacement top, bottom and connection pieces for the project described below.
I've been spending time with various gear design and testing and came upon the Ferguson's Mechanical Paradox Replica by sawdusty posted May 24, 2013. He stated that he had not printed the design and that he didn't know if it would work. The project was appealing, so I decided to try making it. I printed the parts as shown in the photos and found several issues:
1) The size of the holes for the pointers in the gear shafts are too small to print. I used CuraEngine with 0.35 nozzle and the holes did not print; in addition, the pins on the pointers are very fragile;
2) The pointers don't nest together with sufficient clearance for interference free movement anyway;
3) The shafts on the base for the gears are too large for the gears to insert;
4) The holes for the attachments are not present in the base plates;
5) The attachment pins are too brittle to work anyway (I printed with ABS) given the way the pins are printed -- they may work if you place them on their sides and then are able to clean off the supports without breaking the pins;
6) Slic3r did not like the gears. At all. It would crash when running under MatterControl every time. I used CuraEngine and was successful. Initial printing was done using an 0.5 mm nozzle; the gears printed with significant "waisting", dishing in toward the middle of the gear along one quadrant of the printout, making gear meshing difficult. That waist effect was significantly reduced with the 0.35 nozzle. Not having access to the design files, no attempt was made to modify the gears.
The attached files fix the shaft, pin, and attachment problem -- I did not address the pointer problem, but as shown, one can demonstrate the principle by using a Sharpie on the shafts.

I printed with 60% infill for the gears and mechanism, 80% for the base to make sure the pins were strong.  
My prints were with ABS plastic

author: extwo2

description.text:
This is a small line tensioner made for my Two Up. I made a pulley mod for it and i was having a lot of issues of it loosening over time. I made this to enable me to simply tension the line much like a clothes line tensioner.
Uses a M3 nut and bolt.
Tested with 12lb fishing line (make sure that it doesn't stretch much).

Tap center hole with M3 tap. ( DO NOT DRILL OUT TO 3MM! )
I found the best way to attach fishing line to bolt to allow spinning is to take side cutters right under the head and to cut about half way through the screw. This makes 2 channels that the line can be knotted on. Put a drop of super glue on it and it works fine.
The nut on the backside acts as a jam nut and prevents the tensioner from backing off.

title: Reptile 500 V1 FatShark 600 TVL Camera Mount

description.text:
The Diatone Reptile 500 is dead cat style quad that is aimed at FPV flying and sold by BuddyRC.com and their resellers.
The frame comes with 2 blank fiber boards for the slots to hold a camera, which is fine if your not flying a FPV cam... not so much for using a FPV cam.
So I put together my version of FPV cam holder for a FatShark 600 TVL camera (my favorite cam of choice) for the Reptile500. This mount fits the first slots in both frame plates and utilizes the M3 frame mount holes as well. The mount provides a super rigid mount. Requires QTY 2 M3 x 8 Button head

description.text:
This is a redesigned Huxley inspired by the Prusa simplified Mendel.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4148 It uses the PLA Bushings like
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4434
I modified the scad script to use 6mm rods.
(basically just put in 6mm for rod size and 12mm for width) I have also redesigned the X and Y motor brackets to be able to use nema 14 or 17 motors. The Z now takes 2 nema 14 motors. I designed it around 1/4" threaded rods and #6-32 bolts. It should work with 6mm rods and M6 bolts, but I'm not sure. This should work with the same extruder as the regular Huxley. I believe. The image is of the current build status, it needs the Y Stage and some belts on it before it will go, and an extruder. But the Z movement is working well so far. Edit: Got the belts in and installed on the X Axis
Test Videos here
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rji863B-JnA
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pw6CKZPRubw The design files are in SolidWorks Edit 12-8-10: Found a problem with the X-axis parts.
the bolts used to tighten the rods in place had a nut bigger than the rod, so I put in a slot on the side. This weakened the structure to the point where tightening the bolts enough to keep tension on the belt, it would break the piece. I redesigned them after finding "Undersized Hex Nuts" (McMaster carr part 90760A007 for 6-32) which allow me to insert them the same as prusajr originally had. I also added more material to the sides to help with this. I am currently printing them out for testing. Edit 12-9-10: I added more material to the x-axis parts to make them a bit stiffer again, I didnt get a chance to test the last version, so it may work just fine.

Print out a bunch of stuff and put it together how it makes sense :)
Found out somebody did a nice writeup for the fullsize one, which should be pretty similar to this one.
http://www.reprap.org/wiki/Prusa_Mendel#Assembly BOM: This does not include and of the extruder parts
Printed Parts:
bar-clamp x8
belt-clamp x4
board-clamp x4
vertex x6
x-axis-carriage x1
x-axis-idler x1
x-axis-motor x1
y-bushing-holder x4
y-motor x1
z-top-motor x2 Motors:
X motor : Nema 14 or 17 x1
Y motor : Nema 14 or 17 x1
Z motors : Nema 14 x2
Enough bolts to attach the motors(M3 on mine) Bolts:

1/4-20 nuts x A Bunch
1/4" washers x A Bunch
1/4" Fender Washers x 6 Bearings:
1/4" bearing x3
(I dont know the part number right now but they are 0.625" OD, which is like 16mm if your building in metric) Edit: Current Bar sizes are as follows
Triangle frame threaded rod = 10" x6
Bottom across frame threaded rod = 8" x4
Top across frame threaded rod = 12" x2
Z bottom support threaded rod = 12" x1 Z Threaded movement rod = 8" x2 Z smooth rod = 9" x2
X & Y smooth rod = 11" x4 These are just because I got the smooth rod out of some old printers, and scaled the rest around them. All these dimensions should be able to be scaled up pretty easily. I should be able to get about a 6"x6"x4" printable area. Kind of important
I attached the Z drive rods with some pieces of aluminum rod that I drilled through at 5mm and tapped halfway with 1/4-20. And then put a set screw in the side to hold it to the motor shaft. Im trying to make a printable version of this and still have it be as straight. Here are instructions on how to put together the Z spring loaded antibacklash nut contraption
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k1xQw5gCoGE You will need a nut that is drilled out just bigger than your rod, like this one
http://i.imgur.com/vUNVM.jpg

remixed_from.author: voltivo
remixed_from.title: Freestanding Filament Holder sized for ExcelFil Spools

description.text:
This Spool Holder is only for the XYZ DaVinci 3D Printer. It is meant to hold spools where the inside diameter of the spool is 32mm. It is designed specifically for the big Octave ABS spools (which are 160mm diameter, 100mm wide).
This is a deluxe spool holder in that it incorporates bearings to minimize friction. These bearings are $8-$15.

This Spool Holder is only for the XYZ DaVinci 3D Printer. It is meant to hold spools where the inside diameter of the spool is 32mm. It is designed specifically for the big Octave ABS spools (which are 160mm diameter, 100mm wide).
This is a deluxe spool holder in that it incorporates bearings to minimize friction. These bearings are $8-$15. The model number for the bearing is 5201-2RS. If you google "5201-2RS bearing" you will find lots of places to buy them. I bought mine at my local (small town) hardware store for less than $8 a piece.
The Spool-Holder is hung off of the middle of the back of the unit so that the filament's path is straight in. The top lid of the DaVinci is in the way of this path, so you must run the unit without the top lid or cut a hole in the lid for the filament to pass through to the inside.
I chose to cut a hole in my lid. This voided my warranted but that is okay for me because my DaVinci is completely hacked anyway. (I have holes in quite a few places already.) When I cut the section out of the lid, I built an assembly to cover and re-enforce the cut edges. I also added stops to prevent the lid from leaning against the filament spool when the lid is open (as it is most of the time for me because I always wanna see what's going on in there).
So there are two assemblies here: the Spool-Holder and the Lid-Edge. The Lid-Edge is optional. I would suggest that you build the Spool Holder and try it out with the top-lid removed. And then decide whether to cut your lid. And then do so carefully and with forethought since I cannot guarantee that my dimensions match your model of DaVinci.
Using the XYZ-Slicer program works fine for these parts. I used "Good" quality (.3mm) and no raft or supports except for the shaft. The shaft requires a raft to ensure that it stays stuck to the platen while it is being Printed.
The parts need to filed before they will fit together. The bottom-most layers of each printed part expand slightly. These "flanges" must be filed off (or cut off with an Xacto knife) for proper fit to occur. Also, you will need a round file to clean up the insides of the sleeves.
I used acetone and metal "paper-clamps" to glue the parts together.

comments.text:
sculptris, I often use inflate on a very low strength (often need to follow with smooth again low strength)
to acomplish a rounder brush function. also crease in invert followed by inflate is a useful workflow).
but sculptris is the closest to intuitive (for me) of the 'organic' modeling tools.
tinkercad Is not great, but for the price it's damn good.
no snap, but there is a way to move the "plane" to a object to make subsequent placements easier.
Also, I often use this to center. copy, delete, paste
this is only good to put object center to plane center.
sometimes i group a dummy object with my object to give the center I want,
(this is good when i need to make a number of copies around a fixed point)
then delete dummy(s)
if hiesenberg is your first effort, i suspect you will be far better at sculpting with
sculptris than I am.

title: PrintrBot Jr. - Print Bed Adjustment Knobs and Pegs

description.text:
My PrintrBot Jr. print head was bumping into the screws on the top of the print bed, so I put these parts together to fit in the holes and not interfere with it's operation.
I also wanted an easy to adjust way of leveling the print bed, without having to fumble with those damn little nuts.

• Print it out, I used PLA.

  • I just popped the little nuts into the middle of the adjustment knobs, and used a drop of super glue to keep em in place. (Big ones go in front, small ones go in back).

  • I flipped the screws that came with the PrintrBot Jr., cut off the heads so they were more like a little threaded rod, and super glued em into the bottom of the pegs. Then I wrapped the top of the peg in a wee little piece of blue painters tape, and stuck it em in the holes of the print platform.

  • I found that by stretching the stock springs out, I could get the clearances I needed under the print-bed, to avoid rubbing against the top of the screws that hold it all together.

Print the Lancia Stratos Body with 4 extra shells and 10% infill at a .2 layer height. Carefully snap off and trim away the support structure.
Print Side Windows and Windshield with zero extra shells and zero infill at .2 layer height. Apply a thin layer of glue to the back and press on to the car body.

Most pieces will snap together. If pieces are having trouble fitting, carefully trim with a hobby knife. Add a bit of glue to secure pieces that are loose.

title: MK8 Dual Head Prusa X-Carriage Mount

description.text:
This is a modification of the original Prusa Mendel x-carriage to fit a dual MK8 extruder. This STL version uses 3 linear bearings, but the SCAD can be altered for other mountings. One of the nozzles has to be temporarily removed in order for this to fit on, then attach with (qty 4) 10mm M3 screws.
--Original:
https://github.com/josefprusa/PrusaMendel
--MK8 Example:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/0-4mm-Dual-Head-Nozzle-Extruder-MK8-Extruder-Makerbo-Upgrade-for-3D-Printer-/281289133407?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item417e238d5f

When assembling, make sure to point the fans towards the back along the x-axis timing belt.  If the fans are pointing towards the front, the belt rubs against the motors.  
You may need to clip the corners off when screwing one of the extruders back on.  
If you are having issues aligning the two print heads with the print bed, try rolling tape over one of the two linear bearings to raise that side up.

This is a cup made in the opensource software called Blender (Version 2.72). I was trying to make a simple object, and here it is! The previews aren't real, they are artist's (yeah, right) renditions of what it would look like. (Rendered in Blender Cycles Renderer, Composited in Blender). I have never tested this in a 3D Printer, so PLEASE (with a cherry on top) print this model and then post the results!

This is how I made this object in Blender 2.72:
  • I added a circle, but set the vertices to 8 so that it would be an octagon.
  • I extruded the octagon outward, so that it had thickness.
  • I extruded the whole object upward, then rotated the top faces on the Z axis.
  • I extruded the top, then rotated the new top on the Z, then repeated again and again 'til I got to a good height.
  • I added a face to the bottom so that the cup would have a bottom.
  • I uploaded it to thingiverse.

title: INDEPENDENT SUSPENSION FOR THE SLAM/GPS EOP

description.text:
This suspension replaces the solid axle in the original package. The change allows a greater weight to be carried than was possible with the lighter springs used on the solid axle design.
It requires 3 (or 5, depending on weight) x 85mm longit. springs/shock absorbers (see photo) per end. They are around $4-5 each from hobby stores.
The .3dm available for download with the vehicle now includes this suspension and the original solid axle design.
You will require the springs (these are easily purchases for RC model shops) and 3mm and 5mm bolts and washers.

If you have some transparent filament, make some of these to add flair to all your small, dark spaces!  Includes a reflector to spread the light evenly, like a tea light.  
You'll need a common 5V LED, a watch battery, and some brass shim.  There's a tiny amount of soldering, but it doesn't need to be good soldering (and you could probably find a way to avoid it).

See the PDF diagram for assembly information.
Note that the pointy bit in the middle is there to reflect the light evenly, so it works best if that part is white. UPDATE: smogit had the idea of printing the lamp glass as a thin-shelled solid with 0% fill; if you want to do that, use the lampglass_solid STL file. That way, you can use non-transparent plastic and still get a translucent object.

comments.text: Something else you can use is go to the Dollar Tree and buy, for 1 dollar, some of those tea lights.  Break it apart (not hard to do) and use the flickering candle like LED with the controller board (it is super small) and do the rest like you said.

I have the Suncast slat wall system in my garage and I am always am looking for a pencil. https://www.suncast.com/sw04.html
So, I decided to design a pencil cup that snaps into the slat system to hold pens and pencils. I printed it in optic yellow so I could always find a writing utensil. It is designed for the Suncast slat wall sections which are sold by Home Depot and other home improvement centers.
https://www.suncast.com/sw04.html
https://www.suncast.com/sheds-storage/garage-storage/slat-wall-systems.html

Settings (Suggested)
Raft: On
Supports: On
Infill: 35% Suggested to make sure 'pegs' are strong.
Shells: 3
Layer Height: 0.20mm After printing,clean up and remove raft and supports with an xacto knife. Be careful not to damage pegs during cleaning. File as necessary for good fit in slat board.

comments.text: I like that you've added a decorative pattern to this. I imagine it saved you some filament and print time too! As a bonus, this won't collect as much sawdust as a solid cup.
comments.author: smokeandlights

comments.text: Thank you. Yes, it saved about 20 minutes on print time and a several tenths of a gram on material.I have a couple of more things more for my Slatwall and then back to the pegboard.

title: Bed-Level Camera Mount - Flash Forge Creator Pro / PowerSpec 3D Pro

description.text:
This is an arm and mount to put the guts of an HP HD 2200 web cam in a position to get a bed-level view of yoru build platform. Version 6 is greatly improved. Print with ABS if you plan on using the HBP... my original printed in
PLA was fine... until I started printing in ABS, and then it melted down after a few prints.

You will need to disassemble an HP HD-2200 webcam. It's easy to do, just pull off the front black code, and unscrew 2 screws.
Once you have the guts of it out, you can mount it to the plate and then mount the arm to the corner build plate screw. I found this was a better way than printing it with a hole (greater structural stability).
